title: 109_s1257
content:
CLARIFICATION OF PRIVATE RIGHT OF ACTION AGAINST TERRORIST STATES; DAMAGES. The amendment to Section 1605 of title 28, United States Code, allows for certain actions against foreign states or officials designated as state sponsors of terrorism. This provides a cause of action for liability to a national of the United States. The amendment to Section 1605 of title 28, United States Code, allows for actions against foreign states or officials designated as state sponsors of terrorism for personal injury or death. The removal of a foreign state from designation as a state sponsor of terrorism does not terminate a cause of action arising under this provision. The amendment to Section 1605 of title 28, US Code allows actions against foreign states or officials designated as state sponsors of terrorism for personal injury or death. Actions cannot be maintained if neither the claimant nor the victim was a US national when the acts occurred. The amendment to Section 1605 of title 28, US Code allows actions against foreign states or officials for damages, including punitive damages. Foreign states are vicariously liable for the actions of their officials, employees, or agents. Appeals can be made within 30 days of a final decision under section 1291 of this title. The amendment allows actions against foreign states or officials for damages, including punitive damages, with appeals possible under section 1292 of this title. Section 589 of the Foreign Operations, Export Financing, and Related Programs Appropriations Act, 1997 is repealed. SEC. 2. PROPERTY SUBJECT TO ATTACHMENT EXECUTION. Section 1610 of title 28, United States Code, is amended to allow for the execution of property interests of foreign states or their entities upon judgment, regardless of economic control or profit distribution to the government. The amendment to Section 1610 of title 28, United States Code, allows for the execution of property interests of foreign states or their entities upon judgment, regardless of economic control or profit distribution to the government. This includes considerations such as whether the government is the real beneficiary of the property interest or if establishing it as a separate entity would allow the foreign state to benefit in U.S. courts while avoiding obligations. The amendment to Section 1610 of title 28, United States Code allows for the execution of property interests of foreign states or their entities upon judgment, regardless of economic control or profit distribution to the government. This includes considerations such as whether the government is the real beneficiary of the property interest or if establishing it as a separate entity would allow the foreign state to benefit in U.S. courts while avoiding obligations under the Trading With the Enemy Act or the International Emergency Economic Powers Act. SEC. 3. APPOINTMENT OF SPECIAL MASTERS.

Amends Victims of Crime Act to change the date for investigations. The Attorney General will transfer funds for Special Masters in a specific case.

SEC. 4. LIS PENDENS. In actions filed in a US district court under specific jurisdictional sections, a notice of pending action with attached complaint establishes a lien on real or personal property titled in the defendant's name or controlled by them. The notice is filed by the court clerk and indexed with all named defendants and their controlled entities. Enforcement of liens established by a notice of pending action with attached complaint shall be as provided in title 28, United States Code. The amendments made by this Act apply to any claim for which a foreign state is not immune under section 1605 of title 28, United States Code, arising before, on, or after the date of the enactment of this Act. In cases where an action was dismissed before the enactment of this Act but would be cognizable under the new amendments, the 10-year limitation period provided under section 1605(f) of title 28, United States Code, shall be tolled.
